catalyst.source: The obtained Ag quantum dots modified TiO 2 (Ag/TiO 2 ) shows excellent and stable photocatalytic activity in CO 2 reduction.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into high added-value chemical products has received special attention.Herein, we designed a novel hierarchically porous and defective TiO 2 modified by Ag quantum dots via a hydrothermal process assisted with organic surfactant and subsequently in-situ photodeposition method.The obtained Ag quantum dots modified TiO 2 (Ag/TiO 2 ) shows excellent and stable photocatalytic activity in CO 2 reduction.In addition, the competing H 2 evolution can be completely suppressed.The super photocatalytic activity can be ascribed to the design of hierarchically porous, the intrinsic defects in TiO 2 , the localized surface plasmon resonance of Ag and the synergetic effect between Ag quantum dots and defective TiO 2 , which jointly improves the CO 2 adsorption performance, enhances visible light absorption capacity and accelerates the separation of photogenerated charges.This work may provide a strategy to design and synthesis defective and hierarchically porous metal oxides for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.

Typically, 7.2 g Ti(SO 4 ) 2 were mixed with 30 mL H 2 O and 5 g TPAOH and vigorously stirred at 40 C for 4 h.Next, the resulting solution was hydrothermal treated at 150 C for 16 h.After being cooled to room temperature, the solution was washed three times with distilled water and dried 100 C for 8 h.Finally, the light-gray powder was collected after calcination at 550 C for 4 h. 0.1 mL AgNO 3 aqueous solution (0.2 M) was added into the 100 mL TiO 2 suspension aqueous solution (0.5 g) and stirred for 2 h at room temperature, and then the solution was irradiated for 30 min under Xe light to form Ag quantum dots.After being filtered and washed by water solution, the precipitate was collected after drying at 100 C for 8 h and the final sample was denoted as Ag/TiO 2 . The powder P25 was calcined at 550 C in H 2 /Ar for 4 h and lightyellow defective P25 has been obtained. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku D/Max 2200PC diffractometer with Cu K radiation (40 kV and 40 mA).UV visible absorption spectrum (UV-vis) was investigated by the Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer, and BaSO 4 was selected as the reference sample.Photoluminescence spectra (PL) of the samples were recorded on the Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrometer using a 325 nm excitation wavelength.The nitrogen sorption/desorption curves of the samples were tested on Micromeritics ASAP 3020, and the specific surface area and the pore size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods at -196 C, respectively.The morphologies and the dispersion of Ag of the sample were observed by the Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM, JEOL-2010F) and Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM, FEI, Magellan 400) with a high angle angular dark field (HAADF) detector, and the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) spectrometer was recorded on the TEM (JEOL-2010F).The temperature-programed desorption with CO 2 (CO 2 -TPD) curves were recorded on Micrometrics Chemisorb 2750 instrument attached with ChemiSoft TPx software.The content of Ag was obtained on the Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy analyzer (ICP-OES).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were measured on the ESCAlab 250Xi instrument, and the binding energies were calibrated by the C 1s electron peak (BE 284.8eV).Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on the Nicolet 7000-C instrument.The carbon isotope analysis was carried out on the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent Technologies 7890A-5795C). Based on the above results and discussions, we propose a possible mechanism of the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction on the sample Ag/TiO 2 .The photocatalytic mechanism and the charge transfer for the Ag/TiO 2 are schematically illustrated in Fig. 7d.Under light irradiation, the reduction of CO 2 on the sample Ag/TiO 2 can be implemented via three routes.Firstly, the electrons and holes are generated on the semiconductor TiO 2 .Then, the excited electrons can transfer to the defect sites (Ti 3 -Vo) and further reduce CO 2 to CO (route i), similar to previous report 36.Therefore, the pure hierarchically porous TiO 2 with rich defect sites shows good photocatalytic activity in the CO 2 reduction (Fig. 7b).Secondly, the modification of Ag quantum dots on the support TiO 2 also further improve the photocatalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 7b.It is because Ag as cocatalyst can rapidly capture photogenerated electrons from the TiO 2 and accelerate the separation efficiency of photogenerated charges.Finally, the captured electrons on the Ag quantum dots would react with the adsorbed CO 2 molecules to produce CO (route ii).In the photoreduction of CO 2 , the presence of Ag quantum dots not only improves the visible light absorption performance (Fig. 6a), but also promotes the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes (Fig. 6b).More importantly, more hot electrons are also generated on metal Ag due to SPR effect (route iii), the produced hot plasmonic electrons can further transfer to the TiO 2 nanoparticles or adjacent metal Ag and reduce CO 2 to CO.Therefore, the sample Ag/TiO 2 shows better performance in the CO 2 reduction compared with the sample TiO 2 , which can be ascribed to the synergetic effects between Ag and TiO 2 .Meanwhile, the photo-induced holes on the TiO 2 would oxidize H 2 O into OH.

catalyst.context: The defective TiO 2 nanoparticles with hierarchically porous structure have been successfully prepared by a hydrothermal process assisted with organic surfactant, and Ag quantum dot as a cocatalyst have been uniformly stabilized on the surface of TiO 2 nanoparticles via in-situ photodeposition methods.As anticipated, the obtained samples TiO 2 and Ag/TiO 2 exhibit excellent and stable photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance compared to commercial TiO 2 .The super photocatalytic activity can be attributed to the design of hierarchically porous structure, the creature of defects and the modification of Ag quantum dots, which can significantly improve the CO 2 adsorption capacity and visible light absorption performance, and greatly accelerate the separation of photogenerated charges.Additionally, the synergetic effect between Ag and TiO 2 can further promote CO 2 adsorption and the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs via the Schootty barrier, which makes it own enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity. co-catalyst.context: The defective TiO 2 nanoparticles with hierarchically porous structure have been successfully prepared by a hydrothermal process assisted with organic surfactant, and Ag quantum dot as a cocatalyst have been uniformly stabilized on the surface of TiO 2 nanoparticles via in-situ photodeposition methods.As anticipated, the obtained samples TiO 2 and Ag/TiO 2 exhibit excellent and stable photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance compared to commercial TiO 2 .The super photocatalytic activity can be attributed to the design of hierarchically porous structure, the creature of defects and the modification of Ag quantum dots, which can significantly improve the CO 2 adsorption capacity and visible light absorption performance, and greatly accelerate the separation of photogenerated charges.Additionally, the synergetic effect between Ag and TiO 2 can further promote CO 2 adsorption and the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs via the Schootty barrier, which makes it own enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity. light source.context: Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, AR, 25 wt) was purchased from Aladdin, China.Titanium sulfate (Ti(SO 4 ) 2 , CR), commercial TiO 2 (CR), reference P25 (CR) and silver nitrate (AgNO 3 , CR) were provided from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd without further purification in this work. Typically, 7.2 g Ti(SO 4 ) 2 were mixed with 30 mL H 2 O and 5 g TPAOH and vigorously stirred at 40 C for 4 h.Next, the resulting solution was hydrothermal treated at 150 C for 16 h.After being cooled to room temperature, the solution was washed three times with distilled water and dried 100 C for 8 h.Finally, the light-gray powder was collected after calcination at 550 C for 4 h. 0.1 mL AgNO 3 aqueous solution (0.2 M) was added into the 100 mL TiO 2 suspension aqueous solution (0.5 g) and stirred for 2 h at room temperature, and then the solution was irradiated for 30 min under Xe light to form Ag quantum dots.After being filtered and washed by water solution, the precipitate was collected after drying at 100 C for 8 h and the final sample was denoted as Ag/TiO 2 . The powder P25 was calcined at 550 C in H 2 /Ar for 4 h and lightyellow defective P25 has been obtained. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku D/Max 2200PC diffractometer with Cu K radiation (40 kV and 40 mA).UV visible absorption spectrum (UV-vis) was investigated by the Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer, and BaSO 4 was selected as the reference sample.Photoluminescence spectra (PL) of the samples were recorded on the Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrometer using a 325 nm excitation wavelength.The nitrogen sorption/desorption curves of the samples were tested on Micromeritics ASAP 3020, and the specific surface area and the pore size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods at -196 C, respectively.The morphologies and the dispersion of Ag of the sample were observed by the Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM, JEOL-2010F) and Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM, FEI, Magellan 400) with a high angle angular dark field (HAADF) detector, and the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) spectrometer was recorded on the TEM (JEOL-2010F).The temperature-programed desorption with CO 2 (CO 2 -TPD) curves were recorded on Micrometrics Chemisorb 2750 instrument attached with ChemiSoft TPx software.The content of Ag was obtained on the Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy analyzer (ICP-OES).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were measured on the ESCAlab 250Xi instrument, and the binding energies were calibrated by the C 1s electron peak (BE 284.8eV).Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on the Nicolet 7000-C instrument.The carbon isotope analysis was carried out on the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent Technologies 7890A-5795C). The photoelectrochemical tests were conducted in Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) solution on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as light source.A Pt sheet and Ag/AgCl electrode were used as opposite and reference electrode, respectively.In the preparing process of work electrode, 40 mg of catalyst was dispersed into 1 mL ethanol by ultrasonic technique to form a slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on carbon paper with an area of 2 cm 2 and dried at 100 C for 4 h. Based on the above results and discussions, we propose a possible mechanism of the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction on the sample Ag/TiO 2 .The photocatalytic mechanism and the charge transfer for the Ag/TiO 2 are schematically illustrated in Fig. 7d.Under light irradiation, the reduction of CO 2 on the sample Ag/TiO 2 can be implemented via three routes.Firstly, the electrons and holes are generated on the semiconductor TiO 2 .Then, the excited electrons can transfer to the defect sites (Ti 3 -Vo) and further reduce CO 2 to CO (route i), similar to previous report 36.Therefore, the pure hierarchically porous TiO 2 with rich defect sites shows good photocatalytic activity in the CO 2 reduction (Fig. 7b).Secondly, the modification of Ag quantum dots on the support TiO 2 also further improve the photocatalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 7b.It is because Ag as cocatalyst can rapidly capture photogenerated electrons from the TiO 2 and accelerate the separation efficiency of photogenerated charges.Finally, the captured electrons on the Ag quantum dots would react with the adsorbed CO 2 molecules to produce CO (route ii).In the photoreduction of CO 2 , the presence of Ag quantum dots not only improves the visible light absorption performance (Fig. 6a), but also promotes the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes (Fig. 6b).More importantly, more hot electrons are also generated on metal Ag due to SPR effect (route iii), the produced hot plasmonic electrons can further transfer to the TiO 2 nanoparticles or adjacent metal Ag and reduce CO 2 to CO.Therefore, the sample Ag/TiO 2 shows better performance in the CO 2 reduction compared with the sample TiO 2 , which can be ascribed to the synergetic effects between Ag and TiO 2 .Meanwhile, the photo-induced holes on the TiO 2 would oxidize H 2 O into OH.
